subject: Sleep
title: Sleep in Ancient Greece
description: A fast breakdown of Sleep in Ancient Greece for builders.

hook.text: The Greeks built temples where sick people came to sleep, believing the god of healing would cure them in dreams.

buildup.text: Asclepion temples practiced dream incubation. Patients fasted, bathed, and then slept on the temple floor.

discovery.text: Priests interpreted the dreams as diagnostic messages from Asclepius, the god of medicine.

twist.text: Some patients actually recovered, likely due to rest, reduced stress, and the placebo effect of ritual healing.

climax.text: This tradition lasted over a thousand years and influenced Hippocrates, who noted sleep's role in healing.

punchline.text: The ancient Greek prescription for illness was often: go to sleep.

quiz.question: What was dream incubation in ancient Greek temples?
options: A form of punishment for criminals
Sleeping in healing temples to receive diagnostic dreams from gods
A method of preserving food overnight
